tools.name: calendar-add_event_on_calendar
tools.description: Add an event on Google calendar

start.description: (inclusive) start time of the event. start time of the first instance for a recurring event. example: '2011-06-03T10:00:00-07:00'
start.title: Start

end.description: (exclusive) end time of the event. end time of the first instance for a recurring event. example: '2011-06-03T10:00:00-07:00'
end.title: End

location.description: Geographic location of the event as free-form text. Optional
location.title: Location

description.description: Description of the event. Can contain HTML. Optional.
description.title: Description

recurrence.description: List of RRULE lines for a recurring event, as specified in RFC5545. example: ['RRULE:FREQ=DAILY;COUNT=2']
recurrence.title: Recurrence

attendees.description: List of attendees of the event. example: [{'email':'john@pallassecurity.com', 'email':'jane@pallassecurity.com'}]
attendees.title: Attendees

tools.name: calendar-search_events_on_calendar
tools.description: Search for all events on Google Calendar

query.description: Free text search terms to find events that match these terms in the following fields: summary, description, location
query.title: Query

max_results.description: Maximum number of events returned on one result page
max_results.title: Max Results

time_max.description: Upper bound (exclusive) for an event's start time to filter by. example: '2011-06-03T10:00:00-07:00'
time_max.title: Time Max

time_min.description: Lower bound (exclusive) for an event's start time to filter by. example: '2011-06-03T10:00:00-07:00'
time_min.title: Time Min

page_token.description: Token specifying which result page to return. Optional.
page_token.title: Page Token

tools.name: drata-get_policies
tools.description:
Retrieve security and compliance policies from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns all policies configured in Drata, including security policies,
compliance procedures, and organizational guidelines with their approval status.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing policy data with fields like id, name, description,
    category, status, approval_date, version, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_user_policies
tools.description:
Retrieve user policy assignments from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about which policies are assigned to which users,
including acknowledgment status and compliance tracking.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing user policy data with fields like id, user_id,
    policy_id, assigned_date, acknowledged, status, etc.

tools.name: drata-test_connection
tools.description:
Test the connection to the Drata API.

This endpoint tests the API connection and URL construction by making a request
to the user-identities/infrastructure endpoint.

Returns:
    Dictionary containing the API response or error message.

tools.name: drata-get_company_info
tools.description:
Get company info.

This endpoint returns information about the company.

Returns:
    Dictionary containing company info.

tools.name: drata-get_frameworks
tools.description:
Retrieve compliance frameworks from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about compliance frameworks (SOC 2, ISO 27001,
HIPAA, etc.) that your organization is working towards or has achieved.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing framework data with fields like id, name, description,
    status, controls_count, completion_percentage, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_questionnaires
tools.description:
Retrieve compliance questionnaires from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about compliance questionnaires, security
assessments, and vendor questionnaires managed through Drata.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing questionnaire data with fields like id, name,
    type, status, questions_count, completion_rate, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_vendors
tools.description:
Retrieve vendor and third-party provider information from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns data about vendors, suppliers, and third-party services
including their risk assessments, compliance status, and contract information.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing vendor data with fields like id, name, category,
    risk_level, compliance_status, contract_details, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_framework_requirements
tools.description:
List framework requirements for the primary workspace, with search and filter options.

Args:
    page: Which page of data are you requesting (optional)
    limit: How many items are you requesting (optional)
    q: Filter data by searching for requirement name or description (optional)
    frameworkSlug: Filter requirements on their framework slug (optional)
    excludeIds: Exclude requirements by array of id (optional)
    excludeControlId: Control id to be excluded (optional)
    isInScope: Filter requirements if they are in/out of scope (optional)
    isReady: Filter requirements if they are or not ready (optional)
    isInScopeControls: Filter requirements if linked to controls in/out of scope (optional)
    topic: Filter requirements on their topic (optional)
    category: Filter requirements on their category (optional)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing framework requirements data.

tools.name: drata-get_users
tools.description:
Retrieve users from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns a list of all users in your Drata organization, including their
roles, permissions, and account status. Useful for user management and access auditing.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing user data with fields like id, email, name, role, status, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_controls
tools.description:
Retrieve compliance controls from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns all compliance controls configured in your Drata environment,
including control descriptions, implementation status, test results, and evidence.
Essential for compliance monitoring and audit preparation.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, maximum 50; values above 50 will be capped)
    search: Search term to filter controls by name or description (optional)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing control data with fields like id, name, description, 
    framework, status, test_results, evidence, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_control_external_evidence
tools.description:
Get all mapped external evidence to a control.

This endpoint returns all external evidence mapped to a control by control id, with optional pagination and exclusion.

Args:
    id: Control ID (required, path parameter)
    page: Which page of data are you requesting (optional)
    limit: How many items are you requesting (optional)
    excludeIds: Exclude external evidence by array of id (optional)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing external evidence data for the control.

tools.name: drata-get_companies
tools.description:
Retrieve companies from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about companies/organizations configured in Drata,
including company details, settings, and configuration data.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing company data with fields like id, name, domain, settings, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_risk_library
tools.description:
Retrieve risk library templates from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns pre-defined risk templates and categories available
in Drata's risk library for risk assessment and management.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing risk library data with fields like id, name,
    category, description, default_severity, mitigation_guidance, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_events
tools.description:
Retrieve audit events and activity logs from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns audit trail events, user activities, system changes,
and other important events tracked by Drata for compliance purposes.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing event data with fields like id, type, timestamp,
    user, description, resource_affected, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_connections
tools.description:
Retrieve integration connections from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about connected services, integrations,
and data sources that Drata monitors for compliance purposes.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing connection data with fields like id, name, type,
    status, last_sync, configuration, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_evidence_library
tools.description:
Retrieve evidence library items from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns compliance evidence, documentation, screenshots,
and other artifacts collected and stored in Drata's evidence library.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing evidence data with fields like id, name, type,
    control_id, upload_date, file_size, description, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_workspace_frameworks
tools.description:
List frameworks by workspace id.

This endpoint returns a list of frameworks for a given workspace id, with optional filters for pagination, search, and readiness.

Args:
    id: Workspace ID (required, path parameter)
    page: Which page of data are you requesting (optional)
    limit: How many items are you requesting (optional)
    q: Filter data by searching for framework names (optional)
    excludeIds: Exclude frameworks by array of id (optional)
    getAll: Return all frameworks? (optional)
    isReady: Filter controls on if they are ready (optional)
    isEnabled: Filter frameworks enabled (optional)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing frameworks data for the workspace.

tools.name: drata-get_workspaces
tools.description:
List workspaces for an account.

This endpoint returns a list of workspaces for the account, with optional pagination and search.

Args:
    page: Which page of data are you requesting (optional)
    limit: How many items are you requesting (optional)
    q: Filter data to search term (optional)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing workspace data.

tools.name: drata-get_assets
tools.description:
Retrieve IT assets from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about IT assets, infrastructure components,
and resources tracked by Drata for compliance and security monitoring.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing asset data with fields like id, name, type,
    owner, location, status, last_scanned, vulnerabilities, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_devices
tools.description:
Retrieve device information from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about employee devices, endpoints,
and hardware tracked by Drata for security and compliance purposes.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing device data with fields like id, name, type,
    owner, os_version, security_status, last_seen, compliance_status, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_personnel
tools.description:
Retrieve personnel records from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about personnel/employees tracked in Drata,
including their roles, access levels, training status, and compliance-related data.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing personnel data with fields like id, name, email,
    department, role, training_status, access_level, etc.

tools.name: drata-get_risks
tools.description:
Retrieve identified risks from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns information about identified security and compliance risks, their severity levels, mitigation strategies, and current status. (Uses /risk-management)

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional)
    sort: Which type of sort (optional)
    sortDir: Which direction to sort the data (optional)
    q: Query to find a risks (optional)
    applicable: Filter risks by applicable (optional)
    status: Filter risks status (optional)
    isScored: Filter risks by scored or not scored (optional)
    treatmentPlan: Filter risks by treatment plan (optional)
    categoriesIds: List of categories ids to find risks by (optional)
    ownersIds: List of owners ids to find risks by (optional)
    needsAttention: Filter risks by controls that are not ready (optional)
    impact: Filter by the impact (optional)
    likelihood: Filter by the likelihood (optional)
    minScore: Filter by the range of scores (optional)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing risk data.

tools.name: drata-get_user_identities
tools.description:
Retrieve user identity information from your Drata organization.

This endpoint returns user identity data including authentication methods,
identity providers, and access credentials managed through Drata.

Args:
    page: Page number for pagination (optional, starts at 1)
    limit: Number of results per page (optional, default varies by endpoint)

Returns:
    Dictionary containing user identity data with fields like id, user_id,
    identity_provider, authentication_method, status, etc.

tools.name: ms365-create-planner-task
tools.description: create-planner-task

id.description: The unique identifier for an entity. Read-only.

activeChecklistItemCount.description: Number of checklist items with value set to false, representing incomplete items.

assigneePriority.description: Hint used to order items of this type in a list view. The format is defined as outlined here.

bucketId.description: Bucket ID to which the task belongs. The bucket needs to be in the plan that the task is in. It's 28 characters long and case-sensitive. Format validation is done on the service.

checklistItemCount.description: Number of checklist items that are present on the task.

completedDateTime.description: Read-only. Date and time at which the 'percentComplete' of the task is set to '100'. The Timestamp type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z

conversationThreadId.description: Thread ID of the conversation on the task. This is the ID of the conversation thread object created in the group.

createdDateTime.description: Read-only. Date and time at which the task is created. The Timestamp type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z

dueDateTime.description: Date and time at which the task is due. The Timestamp type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z

hasDescription.description: Read-only. Value is true if the details object of the task has a nonempty description and false otherwise.

orderHint.description: Hint used to order items of this type in a list view. The format is defined as outlined here.

percentComplete.description: Percentage of task completion. When set to 100, the task is considered completed.

planId.description: Plan ID to which the task belongs.

priority.description: Priority of the task. The valid range of values is between 0 and 10, with the increasing value being lower priority (0 has the highest priority and 10 has the lowest priority).  Currently, Planner interprets values 0 and 1 as 'urgent', 2, 3 and 4 as 'important', 5, 6, and 7 as 'medium', and 8, 9, and 10 as 'low'.  Additionally, Planner sets the value 1 for 'urgent', 3 for 'important', 5 for 'medium', and 9 for 'low'.

referenceCount.description: Number of external references that exist on the task.

startDateTime.description: Date and time at which the task starts. The Timestamp type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z

id.description: The unique identifier for an entity. Read-only.

bodyLastModifiedDateTime.description: The date and time when the task body was last modified. By default, it is in UTC. You can provide a custom time zone in the request header. The property value uses ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2020 would look like this: '2020-01-01T00:00:00Z'.

categories.description: The categories associated with the task. Each category corresponds to the displayName property of an outlookCategory that the user has defined.

createdDateTime.description: The date and time when the task was created. By default, it is in UTC. You can provide a custom time zone in the request header. The property value uses ISO 8601 format. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2020 would look like this: '2020-01-01T00:00:00Z'.

hasAttachments.description: Indicates whether the task has attachments.

isReminderOn.description: Set to true if an alert is set to remind the user of the task.

lastModifiedDateTime.description: The date and time when the task was last modified. By default, it is in UTC. You can provide a custom time zone in the request header. The property value uses ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2020 would look like this: '2020-01-01T00:00:00Z'.

title.description: A brief description of the task.

attachments.description: A collection of file attachments for the task.

checklistItems.description: A collection of checklistItems linked to a task.

extensions.description: The collection of open extensions defined for the task. Nullable.

linkedResources.description: A collection of resources linked to the task.

tools.name: ms365-create-calendar-event
tools.description: create-calendar-event

allowNewTimeProposals.description: true if the meeting organizer allows invitees to propose a new time when responding; otherwise, false. Optional. The default is true.

attendees.description: The collection of attendees for the event.

bodyPreview.description: The preview of the message associated with the event. It's in text format.

hasAttachments.description: Set to true if the event has attachments.

hideAttendees.description: When set to true, each attendee only sees themselves in the meeting request and meeting Tracking list. The default is false.

iCalUId.description: A unique identifier for an event across calendars. This ID is different for each occurrence in a recurring series. Read-only.

isAllDay.description: Set to true if the event lasts all day. If true, regardless of whether it's a single-day or multi-day event, start, and endtime must be set to midnight and be in the same time zone.

isCancelled.description: Set to true if the event has been canceled.

isDraft.description: Set to true if the user has updated the meeting in Outlook but hasn't sent the updates to attendees. Set to false if all changes are sent, or if the event is an appointment without any attendees.

isOnlineMeeting.description: True if this event has online meeting information (that is, onlineMeeting points to an onlineMeetingInfo resource), false otherwise. Default is false (onlineMeeting is null). Optional.  After you set isOnlineMeeting to true, Microsoft Graph initializes onlineMeeting. Subsequently, Outlook ignores any further changes to isOnlineMeeting, and the meeting remains available online.

isOrganizer.description: Set to true if the calendar owner (specified by the owner property of the calendar) is the organizer of the event (specified by the organizer property of the event). It also applies if a delegate organized the event on behalf of the owner.

isReminderOn.description: Set to true if an alert is set to remind the user of the event.

locations.description: The locations where the event is held or attended from. The location and locations properties always correspond with each other. If you update the location property, any prior locations in the locations collection are removed and replaced by the new location value.

onlineMeetingUrl.description: A URL for an online meeting. The property is set only when an organizer specifies in Outlook that an event is an online meeting such as Skype. Read-only.To access the URL to join an online meeting, use joinUrl which is exposed via the onlineMeeting property of the event. The onlineMeetingUrl property will be deprecated in the future.

originalEndTimeZone.description: The end time zone that was set when the event was created. A value of tzone://Microsoft/Custom indicates that a legacy custom time zone was set in desktop Outlook.

originalStart.description: Represents the start time of an event when it's initially created as an occurrence or exception in a recurring series. This property is not returned for events that are single instances. Its date and time information is expressed in ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z

originalStartTimeZone.description: The start time zone that was set when the event was created. A value of tzone://Microsoft/Custom indicates that a legacy custom time zone was set in desktop Outlook.

reminderMinutesBeforeStart.description: The number of minutes before the event start time that the reminder alert occurs.

responseRequested.description: Default is true, which represents the organizer would like an invitee to send a response to the event.

seriesMasterId.description: The ID for the recurring series master item, if this event is part of a recurring series.

subject.description: The text of the event's subject line.

transactionId.description: A custom identifier specified by a client app for the server to avoid redundant POST operations in case of client retries to create the same event. It's useful when low network connectivity causes the client to time out before receiving a response from the server for the client's prior create-event request. After you set transactionId when creating an event, you can't change transactionId in a subsequent update. This property is only returned in a response payload if an app has set it. Optional.

webLink.description: The URL to open the event in Outlook on the web.Outlook on the web opens the event in the browser if you are signed in to your mailbox. Otherwise, Outlook on the web prompts you to sign in.This URL can't be accessed from within an iFrame.

attachments.description: The collection of FileAttachment, ItemAttachment, and referenceAttachment attachments for the event. Navigation property. Read-only. Nullable.

extensions.description: The collection of open extensions defined for the event. Nullable.

instances.description: The occurrences of a recurring series, if the event is a series master. This property includes occurrences that are part of the recurrence pattern, and exceptions modified, but doesn't include occurrences cancelled from the series. Navigation property. Read-only. Nullable.

multiValueExtendedProperties.description: The collection of multi-value extended properties defined for the event. Read-only. Nullable.

singleValueExtendedProperties.description: The collection of single-value extended properties defined for the event. Read-only. Nullable.

bodyPreview.description: The preview of the message associated with the event. It's in text format.

hasAttachments.description: Set to true if the event has attachments.

hideAttendees.description: When set to true, each attendee only sees themselves in the meeting request and meeting Tracking list. The default is false.

iCalUId.description: A unique identifier for an event across calendars. This ID is different for each occurrence in a recurring series. Read-only.

isAllDay.description: Set to true if the event lasts all day. If true, regardless of whether it's a single-day or multi-day event, start, and endtime must be set to midnight and be in the same time zone.

isCancelled.description: Set to true if the event has been canceled.

isDraft.description: Set to true if the user has updated the meeting in Outlook but hasn't sent the updates to attendees. Set to false if all changes are sent, or if the event is an appointment without any attendees.

isOnlineMeeting.description: True if this event has online meeting information (that is, onlineMeeting points to an onlineMeetingInfo resource), false otherwise. Default is false (onlineMeeting is null). Optional.  After you set isOnlineMeeting to true, Microsoft Graph initializes onlineMeeting. Subsequently, Outlook ignores any further changes to isOnlineMeeting, and the meeting remains available online.

isOrganizer.description: Set to true if the calendar owner (specified by the owner property of the calendar) is the organizer of the event (specified by the organizer property of the event). It also applies if a delegate organized the event on behalf of the owner.

isReminderOn.description: Set to true if an alert is set to remind the user of the event.

locations.description: The locations where the event is held or attended from. The location and locations properties always correspond with each other. If you update the location property, any prior locations in the locations collection are removed and replaced by the new location value.

onlineMeetingUrl.description: A URL for an online meeting. The property is set only when an organizer specifies in Outlook that an event is an online meeting such as Skype. Read-only.To access the URL to join an online meeting, use joinUrl which is exposed via the onlineMeeting property of the event. The onlineMeetingUrl property will be deprecated in the future.

originalEndTimeZone.description: The end time zone that was set when the event was created. A value of tzone://Microsoft/Custom indicates that a legacy custom time zone was set in desktop Outlook.

originalStart.description: Represents the start time of an event when it's initially created as an occurrence or exception in a recurring series. This property is not returned for events that are single instances. Its date and time information is expressed in ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z

originalStartTimeZone.description: The start time zone that was set when the event was created. A value of tzone://Microsoft/Custom indicates that a legacy custom time zone was set in desktop Outlook.

reminderMinutesBeforeStart.description: The number of minutes before the event start time that the reminder alert occurs.

responseRequested.description: Default is true, which represents the organizer would like an invitee to send a response to the event.

seriesMasterId.description: The ID for the recurring series master item, if this event is part of a recurring series.

subject.description: The text of the event's subject line.

transactionId.description: A custom identifier specified by a client app for the server to avoid redundant POST operations in case of client retries to create the same event. It's useful when low network connectivity causes the client to time out before receiving a response from the server for the client's prior create-event request. After you set transactionId when creating an event, you can't change transactionId in a subsequent update. This property is only returned in a response payload if an app has set it. Optional.

webLink.description: The URL to open the event in Outlook on the web.Outlook on the web opens the event in the browser if you are signed in to your mailbox. Otherwise, Outlook on the web prompts you to sign in.This URL can't be accessed from within an iFrame.

attachments.description: The collection of FileAttachment, ItemAttachment, and referenceAttachment attachments for the event. Navigation property. Read-only. Nullable.

extensions.description: The collection of open extensions defined for the event. Nullable.

instances.description: The occurrences of a recurring series, if the event is a series master. This property includes occurrences that are part of the recurrence pattern, and exceptions modified, but doesn't include occurrences cancelled from the series. Navigation property. Read-only. Nullable.

multiValueExtendedProperties.description: The collection of multi-value extended properties defined for the event. Read-only. Nullable.

singleValueExtendedProperties.description: The collection of single-value extended properties defined for the event. Read-only. Nullable.

id.description: The unique identifier for an entity. Read-only.

bodyLastModifiedDateTime.description: The date and time when the task body was last modified. By default, it is in UTC. You can provide a custom time zone in the request header. The property value uses ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2020 would look like this: '2020-01-01T00:00:00Z'.

categories.description: The categories associated with the task. Each category corresponds to the displayName property of an outlookCategory that the user has defined.

createdDateTime.description: The date and time when the task was created. By default, it is in UTC. You can provide a custom time zone in the request header. The property value uses ISO 8601 format. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2020 would look like this: '2020-01-01T00:00:00Z'.

hasAttachments.description: Indicates whether the task has attachments.

isReminderOn.description: Set to true if an alert is set to remind the user of the task.

lastModifiedDateTime.description: The date and time when the task was last modified. By default, it is in UTC. You can provide a custom time zone in the request header. The property value uses ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2020 would look like this: '2020-01-01T00:00:00Z'.

title.description: A brief description of the task.

attachments.description: A collection of file attachments for the task.

checklistItems.description: A collection of checklistItems linked to a task.

extensions.description: The collection of open extensions defined for the task. Nullable.

linkedResources.description: A collection of resources linked to the task.

bccRecipients.description: The Bcc: recipients for the message.

bodyPreview.description: The first 255 characters of the message body. It is in text format.

ccRecipients.description: The Cc: recipients for the message.

conversationId.description: The ID of the conversation the email belongs to.

conversationIndex.description: Indicates the position of the message within the conversation.

hasAttachments.description: Indicates whether the message has attachments. This property doesn't include inline attachments, so if a message contains only inline attachments, this property is false. To verify the existence of inline attachments, parse the body property to look for a src attribute, such as .

internetMessageHeaders.description: A collection of message headers defined by RFC5322. The set includes message headers indicating the network path taken by a message from the sender to the recipient. It can also contain custom message headers that hold app data for the message.  Returned only on applying a $select query option. Read-only.

internetMessageId.description: The message ID in the format specified by RFC2822.

isDeliveryReceiptRequested.description: Indicates whether a read receipt is requested for the message.

isDraft.description: Indicates whether the message is a draft. A message is a draft if it hasn't been sent yet.

isRead.description: Indicates whether the message has been read.

isReadReceiptRequested.description: Indicates whether a read receipt is requested for the message.

parentFolderId.description: The unique identifier for the message's parent mailFolder.

receivedDateTime.description: The date and time the message was received.  The date and time information uses ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z.

replyTo.description: The email addresses to use when replying.

sentDateTime.description: The date and time the message was sent.  The date and time information uses ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z.

toRecipients.description: The To: recipients for the message.

webLink.description: The URL to open the message in Outlook on the web.You can append an ispopout argument to the end of the URL to change how the message is displayed. If ispopout is not present or if it is set to 1, then the message is shown in a popout window. If ispopout is set to 0, the browser shows the message in the Outlook on the web review pane.The message opens in the browser if you are signed in to your mailbox via Outlook on the web. You are prompted to sign in if you are not already signed in with the browser.This URL cannot be accessed from within an iFrame.

attachments.description: The fileAttachment and itemAttachment attachments for the message.

extensions.description: The collection of open extensions defined for the message. Nullable.

multiValueExtendedProperties.description: The collection of multi-value extended properties defined for the message. Nullable.

singleValueExtendedProperties.description: The collection of single-value extended properties defined for the message. Nullable.

tools.name: docs-docs_batch_stylize
tools.description:
Batch apply multiple styling operations to a Google Docs document.
You MUST call the tool docs_get_document before running this tool OR run this tool immediately after running the tool docs_create_document.
It's preferred that you first apply all textual changes and then call this tool to batch apply all styling changes in one go.
Operations are applied in descending order of start_index to avoid index shifting issues.

tools.name: docs-docs_create_footnotes
tools.description:
Create multiple footnotes in a Google Docs document.
You MUST call the tool docs_get_document before running this tool OR run this tool immediately after running the tool docs_create_document.
You MUST precisely count the exact indexes for the footnotes before running this tool.
It's preferred that you first apply all textual changes and then call this tool to batch apply all footnotes in one go.
Footnotes with Location are processed first (in descending index order),
followed by footnotes with EndOfSegmentLocation.

in_trash.description: Set to true to delete a block. Set to false to restore a block.

tools.name: notion-API-post-search
tools.description: Search Notion by page title

query.description: The text that the API compares page and database titles against.

sort.description: A set of criteria, `direction` and `timestamp` keys, that orders the results. The **only** supported timestamp value is `"last_edited_time"`. Supported `direction` values are `"ascending"` and `"descending"`. If `sort` is not provided, then the most recently edited results are returned first.

direction.description: The direction to sort. Possible values include `ascending` and `descending`.

timestamp.description: The name of the timestamp to sort against. Possible values include `last_edited_time`.

filter.description: A set of criteria, `value` and `property` keys, that limits the results to either only pages or only databases. Possible `value` values are `"page"` or `"database"`. The only supported `property` value is `"object"`.

value.description: The value of the property to filter the results by.  Possible values for object type include `page` or `database`.  **Limitation**: Currently the only filter allowed is `object` which will filter by type of object (either `page` or `database`)

property.description: The name of the property to filter by. Currently the only property you can filter by is the object type.  Possible values include `object`.   Limitation: Currently the only filter allowed is `object` which will filter by type of object (either `page` or `database`)

start_cursor.description: A `cursor` value returned in a previous response that If supplied, limits the response to results starting after the `cursor`. If not supplied, then the first page of results is returned. Refer to [pagination](https://developers.notion.com/reference/intro#pagination) for more details.

page_size.description: The number of items from the full list to include in the response. Maximum: `100`.

tools.name: gdrive-search_files_on_google_drive
tools.description:
Search for files on Google Drive.

Args:
    query: A query for filtering the file results. MUST NOT be empty. The query string contains the following three parts: "query_term operator values", where
        1) query_term is the query term or field to search upon.
        2) operator specifies the condition for the query term.
        3) values are the specific values you want to use to filter your search results.
    page_size: The maximum number of files to return per page. Partial or empty result pages are possible even before the end of the files list has been reached.
    page_token: The token for continuing a previous list request on the next page. This should be set to the value of 'nextPageToken' from the previous response. Leave empty each time you make a new query.

Examples:
    query:"mimeType = 'image/jpeg'"
    query:"name = 'hello'"
    query:"modifiedTime > '2012-06-04T12:00:00' and (mimeType contains 'image/' or mimeType contains 'video/')"

tools.name: slack-slack_human_ts_to_slack_ts
tools.description: Convert human-readable timestamps to Slack timestamp format. MANDATORY: AI agents MUST use this tool for any human-readable to Slack timestamp conversion instead of attempting manual conversion. Accepts timestamps in ISO 8601 format or unambiguous formats like 'January 15, 2024 10:30:45'.

timestamps.description: Array of human-readable timestamps to convert. Use unambiguous formats like 'January 15, 2024 10:30:45', 'Jan 15, 2024 10:30:45 AM', or ISO 8601 format '2024-01-15T10:30:45'. Avoid region-specific formats like '01/15/2024' vs '15/01/2024'.

timezone.description: Timezone that the input timestamps are in (e.g., 'America/New_York', 'Europe/London', 'Asia/Tokyo'). Defaults to 'UTC' if not specified. Use IANA timezone identifiers.

tools.name: slack-slack_ts_to_human_readable
tools.description: Convert Slack timestamps to human-readable format. MANDATORY: AI agents MUST use this tool for any Slack timestamp conversion instead of attempting manual conversion. Slack timestamps are Unix timestamps with microsecond precision (e.g., '1512085950.000216').

timestamps.description: Array of Slack timestamps to convert. Each timestamp should be in the format '1234567890.123456' (Unix timestamp with microsecond precision).

timezone.description: Target timezone for conversion (e.g., 'America/New_York', 'Europe/London', 'Asia/Tokyo'). Defaults to 'UTC' if not specified. Use IANA timezone identifiers.

tools.name: slack-slack_get_channel_history
tools.description: Get recent messages from a channel

channel_id.description: The ID of the channel. The results are returned paginated. When a non-empty next_cursor value is returned, it means the list is incomplete and can be continued by calling the tool again with next_cursor as the cursor parameter.

pagination_window.description: Results will be returned in batches of this size, so as not to overload the server (default 50, max 50). This is only for efficiency purposes. You should call the tool again to get the next batch.

cursor.description: Pagination cursor for next page of results. This is the next_cursor value of a previous call to the tool. To get the first page of results, don't provide a cursor.

oldest.description: Start of time range of messages to include in results. Unix timestamp (e.g., '1512085950.000216'). Only messages after this timestamp will be included.

latest.description: End of time range of messages to include in results. Unix timestamp (e.g., '1512085950.000216'). Only messages before this timestamp will be included.

inclusive.description: Include messages with oldest or latest timestamps in results. Ignored unless either oldest or latest timestamp is specified.

run_as_user.description: You MUST NOT change the default value of this parameter, unless EXPLICITLY requested to do so by the user. 'true' if the tool should perform actions using the user's identity (default), 'false' if the tool should use its bot identity when performing actions.

tools.name: sfdc-salesforce_query_records
tools.description:
Query records from any Salesforce object using SOQL, including relationship queries.

Examples:
1. Parent-to-child query (e.g., Account with Contacts):
   - objectName: "Account"
   - fields: ["Name", "(SELECT Id, FirstName, LastName FROM Contacts)"]

2. Child-to-parent query (e.g., Contact with Account details):
   - objectName: "Contact"
   - fields: ["FirstName", "LastName", "Account.Name", "Account.Industry"]

3. Multiple level query (e.g., Contact -> Account -> Owner):
   - objectName: "Contact"
   - fields: ["Name", "Account.Name", "Account.Owner.Name"]

4. Related object filtering:
   - objectName: "Contact"
   - fields: ["Name", "Account.Name"]
   - whereClause: "Account.Industry = 'Technology'"

Note: When using relationship fields:
- Use dot notation for parent relationships (e.g., "Account.Name")
- Use subqueries in parentheses for child relationships (e.g., "(SELECT Id FROM Contacts)")
- Custom relationship fields end in "__r" (e.g., "CustomObject__r.Name")

objectName.description: API name of the object to query

fields.description: List of fields to retrieve, including relationship fields

whereClause.description: WHERE clause, can include conditions on related objects

orderBy.description: ORDER BY clause, can include fields from related objects

limit.description: Maximum number of records to return

tools.name: sfdc-salesforce_dml_records
tools.description:
Perform data manipulation operations on Salesforce records:
  - insert: Create new records
  - update: Modify existing records (requires Id)
  - delete: Remove records (requires Id)
  - upsert: Insert or update based on external ID field
  Examples: Insert new Accounts, Update Case status, Delete old records, Upsert based on custom external ID

operation.description: Type of DML operation to perform

externalIdField.description: External ID field name for upsert operations

tools.name: sfdc-salesforce_execute_anonymous
tools.description:
Execute anonymous Apex code in Salesforce.
  
Examples:
1. Execute simple Apex code:
   {
     "apexCode": "System.debug('Hello World');"
   }

2. Execute Apex code with variables:
   {
     "apexCode": "List<Account> accounts = [SELECT Id, Name FROM Account LIMIT 5]; for(Account a : accounts) { System.debug(a.Name); }"
   }

3. Execute Apex with debug logs:
   {
     "apexCode": "System.debug(LoggingLevel.INFO, 'Processing accounts...'); List<Account> accounts = [SELECT Id FROM Account LIMIT 10]; System.debug(LoggingLevel.INFO, 'Found ' + accounts.size() + ' accounts');",
     "logLevel": "DEBUG"
   }

Notes:
- The apexCode parameter is required and must contain valid Apex code
- The code is executed in an anonymous context and does not persist
- The logLevel parameter is optional (defaults to 'DEBUG')
- Execution results include compilation success/failure, execution success/failure, and debug logs
- For security reasons, some operations may be restricted based on user permissions
- This tool can be used for data operations or updates when there are no other specific tools available
- When users request data queries or updates that aren't directly supported by other tools, this tool can be used if the operation is achievable using Apex code

logLevel.description: Log level for debug logs (optional, defaults to DEBUG)

tools.name: sfdc-salesforce_read_apex_trigger

triggerName.description: Name of a specific Apex trigger to read

namePattern.description: Pattern to match Apex trigger names (supports wildcards * and ?)

includeMetadata.description: Whether to include metadata about the Apex triggers

tools.name: sfdc-salesforce_manage_debug_logs
tools.description:
Manage debug logs for Salesforce users - enable, disable, or retrieve logs.
  
Examples:
1. Enable debug logs for a user:
   {
     "operation": "enable",
     "username": "user@example.com",
     "logLevel": "DEBUG",
     "expirationTime": 30
   }

2. Disable debug logs for a user:
   {
     "operation": "disable",
     "username": "user@example.com"
   }

3. Retrieve debug logs for a user:
   {
     "operation": "retrieve",
     "username": "user@example.com",
     "limit": 5
   }

4. Retrieve a specific log with full content:
   {
     "operation": "retrieve",
     "username": "user@example.com",
     "logId": "07L1g000000XXXXEAA0",
     "includeBody": true
   }

Notes:
- The operation must be one of: 'enable', 'disable', or 'retrieve'
- The username parameter is required for all operations
- For 'enable' operation, logLevel is optional (defaults to 'DEBUG')
- Log levels: NONE, ERROR, WARN, INFO, DEBUG, FINE, FINER, FINEST
- expirationTime is optional for 'enable' operation (minutes until expiration, defaults to 30)
- limit is optional for 'retrieve' operation (maximum number of logs to return, defaults to 10)
- logId is optional for 'retrieve' operation (to get a specific log)
- includeBody is optional for 'retrieve' operation (to include the full log content, defaults to false)
- The tool validates that the specified user exists before performing operations
- If logLevel is not specified when enabling logs, the tool will ask for clarification

operation.description: Operation to perform on debug logs

logLevel.description: Log level for debug logs (required for 'enable' operation)

expirationTime.description: Minutes until the debug log configuration expires (optional, defaults to 30)

limit.description: Maximum number of logs to retrieve (optional, defaults to 10)

logId.description: ID of a specific log to retrieve (optional)

includeBody.description: Whether to include the full log content (optional, defaults to false)

tools.name: sfdc-salesforce_write_apex
tools.description:
Create or update Apex classes in Salesforce.
  
Examples:
1. Create a new Apex class:
   {
     "operation": "create",
     "className": "AccountService",
     "apiVersion": "58.0",
     "body": "public class AccountService { public static void updateAccounts() { /* implementation */ } }"
   }

2. Update an existing Apex class:
   {
     "operation": "update",
     "className": "AccountService",
     "body": "public class AccountService { public static void updateAccounts() { /* updated implementation */ } }"
   }

Notes:
- The operation must be either 'create' or 'update'
- For 'create' operations, className and body are required
- For 'update' operations, className and body are required
- apiVersion is optional for 'create' (defaults to the latest version)
- The body must be valid Apex code
- The className in the body must match the className parameter
- Status information is returned after successful operations

operation.description: Whether to create a new class or update an existing one

className.description: Name of the Apex class to create or update

apiVersion.description: API version for the Apex class (e.g., '58.0')

body.description: Full body of the Apex class

tools.name: sfdc-salesforce_write_apex_trigger
tools.description:
Create or update Apex triggers in Salesforce.
  
Examples:
1. Create a new Apex trigger:
   {
     "operation": "create",
     "triggerName": "AccountTrigger",
     "objectName": "Account",
     "apiVersion": "58.0",
     "body": "trigger AccountTrigger on Account (before insert, before update) { /* implementation */ }"
   }

2. Update an existing Apex trigger:
   {
     "operation": "update",
     "triggerName": "AccountTrigger",
     "body": "trigger AccountTrigger on Account (before insert, before update, after update) { /* updated implementation */ }"
   }

Notes:
- The operation must be either 'create' or 'update'
- For 'create' operations, triggerName, objectName, and body are required
- For 'update' operations, triggerName and body are required
- apiVersion is optional for 'create' (defaults to the latest version)
- The body must be valid Apex trigger code
- The triggerName in the body must match the triggerName parameter
- The objectName in the body must match the objectName parameter (for 'create')
- Status information is returned after successful operations

operation.description: Whether to create a new trigger or update an existing one

triggerName.description: Name of the Apex trigger to create or update

objectName.description: Name of the Salesforce object the trigger is for (required for 'create')

apiVersion.description: API version for the Apex trigger (e.g., '58.0')

body.description: Full body of the Apex trigger

end_arrow.description: The style of the arrow at the end of the line.

start_connection.description: The connection at the start of the line, if any.

end_connection.description: The connection at the end of the line, if any.

x.description: The x-coordinate of the shape's top-left corner. The slide's top-left corner is at (0,0).
x.title: X

y.description: The y-coordinate of the shape's top-left corner. The slide's top-left corner is at (0,0).
y.title: Y

unit.description: The unit of measurement for x and y coordinates.
